t: Proverbs 17
Better*pn is a dry morsel with quiet than*ld a house full of feasting with strife.
A*ln servant who deals wisely will rule over a son who acts shamefully and*ld will share the inheritance as one of the brothers.
The*ln crucible is for silver, and the furnace is for gold, and*ld the Lord*s tests hearts.
An*ln evildoer listens to wicked lips, and*ld a liar gives ear to a mischievous tongue.
Whoever*ln mocks the poor insults his Maker; he*ld who is glad at calamity will not go unpunished.
Grandchildren*ln are the crown of the aged, and*ld the glory of children is their fathers.
Fine*ln speech is not becoming to a fool; still*ld less is false speech to a prince.
A*ln bribe is like a magic stone in the eyes of the one who gives it; wherever*ld he turns he prospers.
Whoever*ln covers an offense seeks love, but*ld he who repeats a matter separates close friends.
A*ln rebuke goes deeper into a man of understanding than*ld a hundred blows into a fool.
An*ln evil man seeks only rebellion, and*ld a cruel messenger will be sent against him.
Let*ln a man meet a she-bear robbed of her cubs rather*ld than a fool in his folly.
If*ln anyone returns evil for good, evil*ld will not depart from his house.
The*ln beginning of strife is like letting out water, so*ld quit before the quarrel breaks out.
He*ln who justifies the wicked and he who condemns the righteous are*ld both alike an abomination to the Lord.*s
Why*ln should a fool have money in his hand to buy wisdom when*ld he has no sense?
A*ln friend loves at all times, and*ld a brother is born for adversity.
One*ln who lacks sense gives a pledge and*ld puts up security in the presence of his neighbor.
Whoever*ln loves transgression loves strife; he*ld who makes his door high seeks destruction.
A*ln man of crooked heart does not discover good, and*ld one with a dishonest tongue falls into calamity.
He*ln who sires a fool gets himself sorrow, and*ld the father of a fool has no joy.
A*ln joyful heart is good medicine, but*ld a crushed spirit dries up the bones.
The*ln wicked accepts a bribe in secret to*ld pervert the ways of justice.
The*ln discerning sets his face toward wisdom, but*ld the eyes of a fool are on the ends of the earth.
A*ln foolish son is a grief to his father and*ld bitterness to her who bore him.
To*ln impose a fine on a righteous man is not good, nor*ld to strike the noble for their uprightness.
Whoever*ln restrains his words has knowledge, and*ld he who has a cool spirit is a man of understanding.
Even*ln a fool who keeps silent is considered wise; when*ld he closes his lips, he is deemed intelligent.
